captions.text:
Good morning John, and thanks for making our
most disliked Vlogbrothers video ever! Apparently,

all you have to do is insult a fictional vigilante.
To be fair, though, to everyone in the comments,
you pretty much got Batman entirely wrong.

Bruce Wayne does contribute to the infrastructure
of that fictional, blighted city as much as

he can, given its deep rooted culture of corruption
that makes it so that there is literally no

one else in the city who can help. Except
for old guy sidekicks number one and number

two and that woman who isn't Katie Holmes
and Jean-Baptiste Emmanuel Zorg.

Of course I know that your video on Tuesday
wasn't really about Batman. It was just using

Batman as a tool to say something: that individual
people cannot have, and do not have, and should

not have the power to change everything on
their own, and when they try to do it, it
always turns out bad.

So, maybe it's odd that we spend so much time
celebrating that idea in our media. But, I

don't actually think it's odd; I think it's
complicated.

Batman's values and actions are a reflection
of our own values and actions, or our desires

to act, to make the world better... in the
ways that we want it to be better.

Of course, then wrapped up in an entertaining
package with great plot and epic explosions
and stuff.

We all do know that there is evil in the world,
so Gotham's underbelly simplifies and represents

that for us. Gotham's criminals aren't a product
of disenfranchisement and undervaluation by

culture. "Some people", as Alfred tells Master
Wayne, "just want to watch the world burn."

So, Batman is a reflection of our anger and
our ambition and our frustration that our

powerlessness to fix the things that we see
is wrong with the world. I think this is fine.

Gotham's evil incarnate is a simplification
of the problems that we face, and Batman is

a simplification of us, of all of us, who
do the good that makes the world work.

So then, in some peculiar way, we are all
bat-people: not the heroes Earth needs, but
the heroes Earth just happened to get.

We build roads and teach children and clean
sewers and invent new kinds of lightbulbs

and care for each other and better ourselves.
It's a simple vigilantism: the vigilantism
of everyday kindness and hard work.

Of course, Batman is a more complex simplification
than, say, Superman, who is so simple that

he's really not even relatable. We see ourselves
in the cracks in his façade, in his anger

and frustration and sadness, because we have
all those things, too.

And for this reflection to work, to sell the
most movie tickets -we're talking about the

movies here, not the comics- Batman has to
be as broadly representative as possible,

so his values are just kind of an average
amalgam of the values of our culture. And

his major characteristics of being hot and
buff and rich and white and male are either

things that we see as unquestionably advantageous
in things that we ourselves would like to

be, or, as like, the default state, which
is I think where we start running into trouble.

My biggest problem with Batman, and to be
fair, all of the mass-cultural movie things

that we spend billions of dollars creating
and marketing, is that in an attempt to represent

most broadly, they continue to under-represent
the same groups over and over and over and

over again! In attempting to reflect our culture
and its weird emphasis on maleness and whiteness

as the default, they don't just submit to
that culture, they help reinforce it, they

help create it, somehow leaving the majority
of people under-represented in a simplification

that had representation as its initial goal,
which is pretty messed up.

So yeah, it's complicated. All simplicity
is a lie!

And we could do a better job. And in comics,
they do a better job. Because the comics don't

cost 500 million dollars to make and thus
can take some risks, which is why that's where
all the interesting stuff happens.
John, I'll see you on Tuesday.

It's October 10th, which means that it's time
to start thinking about the Project for Awesome,

people. We're working on some very cool perks.
One of the things is a compilation album of

nerdfighter music; anything inspired by anything
to do with nerdfighteria. If you wold like

to contribute to that compilation album, there
is some information in the description. What's
happening over on Games with Hank?

UH-OH I'M SORRY DOLPHIN MOM! That is a jellyfish!
Ohh, woahh, look at me goo! Everyone's a winner...

until their legs break in half. No... NoOO-
AAA-HAAAAAA!
Yeah, it-- it's fun. You should come visit.

comments.text:
Ok I am gonna have a mini rant here because I'm seeing this all over the 
comments and I am starting to get a bit miffed.
"Superman is a Mary Sue"
...no.
The problem is that you are applying the internet's bastardized definition 
of "Mary Sue" instead of its actual definition, since many people think 
that the term Mary Sue means "A character who is perfect" which is 
EN-tirely wrong.
A Mary Sue is actually a character who is SO perfect that they are 
unaffected or not threatened by the works of the narrative. That might seem 
like an unnessery alteration but take that into account when looking at 
Superman again, because Superman is constantly challenged by the narrative 
because all the obstacles that he faces are challenging to him. Both 
physically and mentally as well as emotionally.
Superman is threatened physically by Darkside and Doomsday as well as being 
threatened mentally by Lex Luthor who represents everything Superman stands 
against, greed and materialism. Superman is even threatened emotionally in 
the events of the Injustice comic series and when he discovers that Shazam 
was really a 10 year old boy.
Actually a lot of Mary Sue accused characters are no longer Mary Sues when 
you use the actual term, including Goku, Thor and many other characters.﻿

comments.text:
The interesting thing about you noting that Batman (and most other typical 
superheroes) having relatively un-complex development is that it draws a 
parallel in my mind (being a folklore student in university) to the 
treatment of characters in traditional folktales. Characters in folktales 
are deliberately underdeveloped and vague (except for sharing the values of 
the community in which the story is told), which allows the teller and 
audience to more easily imagine themselves in the story. I suppose it could 
be argued that the traditional superhero was kept relatively undeveloped 
for the same purpose. :)﻿

comments.text:
Hank, you've got some good points, and I do like Batman, honestly (if only 
because I started playing Arkham Asylum and I now feel sorry for him). 

But I don't justify his actions, because he's a vigilante who feels 
personally responsible for Gotham, but also endangers it constantly, and is 
unable to neutralise the biggest threats to that very city. 

I have a few small issues with Batman, like his ridiculous expectation that 
he be taken seriously while wearing a *bat costume*, but my major issue is 
this: he never kills the Joker. Or Harley, or Zaaz, or anyone else in that 
group who has proven to be a mass murderer, incorrigible, 10/10 will escape 
to kill again. 

There's something to be said for the desire to rehabilitate rather than 
penalize, and I'm all for that, but not at the cost of innocents. The 
Joker's life, I believe, has great value, and if he could be convinced to 
change his ways and submit to the law of the land, that would be 
great...but everyone knows he's never ever going to do that. And in waiting 
for him to do that, Gotham is allowing him to kill more totally innocent 
people. 

I value the lives of uncaring serial killers, but I care about the lives of 
innocent civilians a heck of a lot more. 

Therefore, I strongly disagree with Batman's repeated refusal to kill the 
Joker, which I feel if he really valued the lives of innocents all that 
much, he would do. ﻿
comments.author: Griffin Raynor

comments.text:
I think Batman is a symbol of Fascism.  The desire of some people for 
widespread social problems to be resolved via draconian punishment and 
"taking matters into our own hands because our institutions are corrupt." 
 Maybe not initially, but ever since Frank Miller got his hands on the 
character in the 80s, Batman and fascism have gone together like very 
expensive wine and beating somebody over the head with an expensive wine 
bottle.

Batman has become the id of the dominant culture.  He is popular for the 
same reason Law and Order is popular, and for the same reason conditions in 
prisons are incredibly shitty.  The Joker exists because of poor mental 
health-care.  Batman punches him repeatedly in the face.  Poison Ivy is a 
feminist and eco-terrorist stereotype.  Batman punches her repeatedly in 
the face.  The Riddler is a confusing intellectual with elitist tendencies. 
 Batman punches him repeatedly in the face.  Mr. Freeze is an amoral 
scientist run amok.  Batman punches him repeatedly in the face.  Killer 
Croc has a disfiguring birth defect.  Batman punches him repeatedly in the 
face.  Bane is a foreigner who worked himself up from nothing.  Batman 
punches him repeatedly in the face. 

Do you notice a pattern?  I notice a pattern.﻿
comments.author: kalinkasixtyfour

comments.text:
As boring as superman may be, a lot of the enemies he fights are people in 
positions of power who abuse those positions, or choose to use their power 
for evil rather than good.  With Batman, everyone he fights is in some way 
a result of the very system he is protecting.  Even the penguin is 
ultimately motivated by an aspiration to be a member of high-society, to be 
a celebrity basically.  Lex Luthor, in virtually every incarnation, is 
motivated by greed or jealousy of superman's power, despite his clear 
brilliance as either a scientist or a businessman (depending on the 
incarnation) giving him the obvious potential to be respected for 
pro-social behavior.

comments.text:
I almost never comment but I think that hank is absolutely wrong about 
Superman. He celebrates the simple experiences involved in being human, but 
that in and of itself is not a simple characterization. His super powers 
are simplistic, because his powers aren't the center of his story. His 
humanity is. The point is to stop and appreciate what makes you Human and 
what makes the Human experience. Superman's comics accomplish this through 
showing us those experiences through a refreshing (non-Human) perspective.﻿

comments.text:
Vlog brothers, how do you find content in a world where everything seems to 
be a paradox?! Sometimes it is hard for me to live day to day being so 
confused with misleading information, and/or manipulation. In some sense it 
could be paranoia but honestly I think I'm just very aware of what's around 
me. Too aware. I'm not saying that I'm completely cynical of everything 
around me but I do struggle with finding truth! It is hard to find trust in 
almost anything, and watching you two for years there is just truth and 
kindness in what you say and how you act. How did you find yourself? How do 
you deal with a world of uncertainty? I see influence around me all time. I 
can see that even I am under influence of conformity to an extent. It is 
constantly on my mind to find truth in myself and I m just very scared of 
getting it all "wrong" because I chose someone else's path. I can never 
fully believe in anything because of this reason and I feel so stuck. I 
just want to know your opinion. ﻿

comments.text:
Well to be fair, most of those examples you cite come from a much more, how 
would you put it, "unenlightened" era. As messed up as things can be today 
they're still much better 99% of the time than they were in the past for 
the majority of people. The concepts of superheroes and icons like Batman 
and Superman and Wolverine, etc. all emerged from periods where the ideas 
of white, male, heterosexualism, etc. were all accepted as the superior 
norm. People today are not trying for the most part to create these types 
of repressive structures, but end up accepting them unconsciously because 
we have inherited these things from our collective cultural experience. 
People usually aren't racist on purpose, it's just something they are 
unconsciously trained to do. We are conditioned by our history to see black 
males as threats and likely to commit crimes, even if you don't dislike 
black people, or have black friends. And this is the biggest problem. 
People don't realize they're being racist when they are brought up in a 
culture like ours, where racist tendencies are not recognized as racism and 
we are all officially recognized as equal, but not socially recognized the 
same.﻿

comments.text:
Actually, we are getting there. As more and more major comic book risks are 
paying off, more of those representative comic arcs are being represented. 
Let's start with TV

There was the Static Shock TV show for starters. Teen Titans gave us the 
black Cyborg. Then Young Justice gave us the black Kaldur'ahm 
(coincidentally voiced by the same guy), the half asian Artemis Crock, and 
the all Hispanic Jaime Reyes. Even the Miles Morales Spider-man is 
appearing on the (mediocre) Ultimate Spider-man cartoon. Don't forget that 
John Stewart's black Green Lantern was the Green Lantern many kids 
including myself grew up with on TV.

But let's talk live action. Arrow introduced the well regarded character of 
John Diggle as Oliver Queen's partner. The Flash is set up to have a black 
Wally West.

Then film,

People forgot that Blade the Vampire Hunter was a thing. And then there was 
Will Smith's utterly badass Hancock. We have the Native Hawaiian Jason 
Momoa set to play Aquaman, and African American Ray Fisher playing Cyborg.

Though we still haven't gotten a South Asian superhero on TV or Movies. The 
best we have is Wonder Black from The Wonderful 101 video game.﻿

comments.text:
A note on underrepresentation.
Lets start off with a disclaimer, i'm not an American, I am Icelandic, the 
whitest country in the world.
That being said, I think it's rediculous to hire actors only to meet a 
racial quota, instead of filling a role with an actor that suits the part 
best. 
Why ?
I'm a very curious guy, and a few years ago i asked the internets about the 
racial demographics in the US of A, and I saw that black people where only 
arround 10%.
10% I couldn't belive it. Many of your most popular musicians are black, 
your best athletes are black, and there's alot of great black actors. 
Knowing that, the presence of african americans in your media is baffling. 
Nothing wrong with that. That's cool. But that statistic says, that they 
are being overrepresented. (not a bad thing). 
Well, perhaps not overrepresented as a main male protagonist, but almost 
every American movie does not follow the demographic. Not saying that 
production executives should follow official racial demographics, but it's 
an interesting thought when you look at casting and racial demographics 
together.

But hey that's just me, the guy from the country with 95% + white people. ﻿

comments.text:
*All* simplicity is not a lie.  It depends on your perspective.  Human 
life, for instance, can be seen simply (consciousness and a body), or seen 
complexly (atoms, molecules, proteins, etc or in the scope of deep time). 
 To say that simplicity is a lie or it is unacceptable to live without 
unpacking all simplicity doesn't sit right with me.  To say the same thing 
for complexity though, is dangerous too.

I'm going against the grain of most academic worldviews here- saying that 
some simplicity is acceptable- but we must realize that, even the best 
scientists and academics among us cannot live in a world of complete 
complexity- it would be absurd.

Also, I can't follow any of your arguments, Hank.  Like, the discourse on 
this channel is super scatterbrained sometimes- both in the videos and the 
comments.  Peace.﻿

Long time listener, first time caller. If I can circumvent the actual 
message of the video and speak on your criticism of Superman, I'd like to 
say that it seems flawed based upon the assumption that both Batman and 
Superman are simplified facsimiles of a collective "us". What Superman 
represents at his core, and has always represented is two things-- the 
choice to do good, when you are so capable of doing bad, and the idea that 
you are not less because you are different. Superman came onto the scene in 
a world where many people, not just Nazis were obsessed with the idea of 
the ideal "Super man". Then comes the story of this amazing person, the 
Nazi Übermensch personified, who not only uses his powers to save the 
common man and help the oppressed, but is an immigrant to boot. ﻿

comments.text:
My theory is that it's because these iconic characters were created 
*decades* ago. Back when POC didn't have equal rights as white people.
And I'm not sure is you've noticed, but throughout the history of comics, 
the characters have been constantly changing. For example, recently, Marvel 
announced Captain America is now going to be taken on by a black person and 
Thor will be taken on by a woman and a new character is in part of the 
Spider-Man comics and she is a female Asian-American. The problem is, they 
will keep on reverting back to the original after a period of time because 
a lot of people can't accept the fact that the characters are changing; 
they prefer the original characters as that is pretty much just human 
nature.
The comic books and movies *do* realise their problem and they *are* trying 
to change it, but if something's not popular (as in people can't get used 
to something, or the original is just loved too much) they will change it 
back.﻿

comments.text:
The reason why minorities are underrepresented in media isn't complicated 
at all we vote for what we want to see by watching what we want. This 
system of voting is more like First past the post as opposed to an MMP 
system.

Imagine a presidential campaign in the US, but instead of parties each race 
puts forward a candidate. If every voter only wants a president they can 
relate to and race is the only difference between candidates, who gets 
elected? The candidate with the most votes ie the white guy at 70ish%.

Now networks and movies serving niche markets are going to skew the numbers 
a little and programs and movies which appeal to people equally(like Key 
and Peele or Dave Chappelle) However you should still expect the plurality 
group to be overrepresented.﻿

comments.text:
I don't think it's discriminating per se to use white male actors in the 
same way that I don't think it's discriminating to use (largely) white male 
character models in video games. I prefer that the focus be put on the 
game, or in this case the story/character, rather than an emphasis on 
political correctness (which is an idea that I've never ascribed to since 
politically correctness can't make up its mind and changes every few 
minutes, it seems.)

I do think it would be amazing to create great stories that represent 
people of all ethnicities and genders. I just don't think that it's a 
justifiable reason to get angry at the movie or gaming industry if they 
don't. They don't owe it to anybody to do that.﻿

comments.text:
Hank is argumenting that because we all kind of are Batman we therefore 
cannot hate him. (And I know that I am oversimlifying and that that is 
execatly what he is critizising ) But that's only partly true, only because 
we can identify with Batman because we also do want the world to change in 
a way that fits with our values and morals and are not able to do just 
that, does not mean that we cannot deteste this (very human) behavior. 
Because just as  pointed out we should know that in order to accomplish 
something we do need to work together and we should be aware (although we 
usually aren't) that our values are not the guidelines according to which 
everybody should act. Hank describes Batman as a personification of anger 
and frustration due to injustice and our inability to change things, but 
this anger may sometimes be helpful and a motivator driving us to at least 
try to change things but also sometimes clouds our judgement and then our 
hate may keep us from doing the "right" thing (which is of course also 
completely subjective, in this case regard the "right" thing as the thing 
this person would do when forced to deal with the same situation but 
without beeing driven by anger, but by some more positive force ( this of 
course only applies if said person is not one of the people who just want 
to see the world burn or do not care about improving the world for anyone 
but themselves)). We are able (if not suffering from antisocial personality 
disorder or beeing blinded by ignorance) to understand other people, their 
values and motivaions (at least a bit) therefore we are able to make more 
rational decisions ( actual groups are even more effective) but when beeing 
driven by anger and frustration these emotions replace our values and 
destroy our ability to collaborate and thereby destroy our abilty to both 
do the "right" thing and to do the more rational thing. Therefore it is 
perfectly fine to identify with Batman (especially due to his flaws) but at 
the same time dislike these common flaws. Our ability to dislike our 
own charcter traits (or in this case the character traits we share with 
Batman) is the basis for our willingness ( and ability, depending on 
wheather you believe people can change or not) to change and therefore our 
ability to improve and actually make the world better (which is by the 
way also one of the named things Batman supposedly stands for). So we might 
should not hate Batman, because we are so similar that we are supposed to 
understand his Motivation, but we can dislike his behavior nevertheless 
just as we can dislike our own flaws.

comments.text:
Excellent!  Hank is on a much better track than John on this.  (Seriously 
though, the movies aren't the best examples of the character.)  Batman is 
the reflection of humanism in the DC Universe.  He is a character that 
faced an tragic loss and used it as a catalyst to transform himself into an 
ideal.  We've watched this character forge alliances, friendships, and 
bonds to help him help others.  While there's this weird notion of him 
"being a loner", he was never alone.  In fact it was his relationships that 
forged him into what he is.

And as for the "issue" of him being a white male, its not some default 
status, its the fact that this was a character created in the late 1930s. 
and the notion of things like "diversity in the medium" weren't a 
consideration at all.  ﻿

comments.text:
Hank though, no offense, but you're not Batman.

Let's take away for a second the fact that in our reality Batman could do 
better for the city just by funding schools rather than a tank of a car to 
physically battle crime with, and acknowledge, for the sake of argument 
that Gotham's fictional universe requires tanks and fists to battle crime 
and nothing else will do. Let's pretend every effort and dollar Batman 
spends battling super villains is, in Gotham's simplified reality, time 
well spent. As you pose in your video. Batman puts an inhuman amount of 
risk and of his personal life into solving the problems facing Gotham.

Now, granted, he's a fictional character and can do things that are, well, 
unrealistic.

But even if you translate Batman's efforts in both risk, energy spent, time 
devoted and money devoted to a realistic human scale in our reality, as 
again you attempt to do in your video.. you are still not even close to 
Batman.

Don't get me wrong, neither am I.

But Batman spends pretty much every waking moment battling crime, and 
battling it directly at its inhuman heart, no matter the risk to himself, 
in the most sensible way to his reality. He doesn't placate evil, or put a 
band-aid over it. He punched it square in the jaw while it shoots poison 
gas at him. Again, in reality this is an ineffective way to battle crime, 
but Batman's world is fictional and so is its crime, as you stated in his 
defense.

Everything about Batman's life revolves completely around battling crime, 
but in the most humane and fair way possible. He doesn't use guns, he 
doesn't kill. He lives up to his ideals 90% of the time even as they put 
him at risk. He specifically battles evil with the intention to not become 
that evil's replacement for a different team.

Even Batman's public life is basically a charade to help his life as 
Batman. At this point, he's not Bruce Wayne posing as Batman to fight 
crime. He's Batman posing as Bruce Wayne to get the bare minimal of food 
and sleep he needs to not die before he heads back to battling crime.

Hank as Batman, in our reality, wouldn't have time for conventions or nerd 
songs or playing video games. You would be 100% your charity work and 
education work about the world's problems. You wouldn't have time to tell 
us about neat scientific discoveries because you'd be busy only fixing the 
world's problems.

You wouldn't be palling around with Bill Gates pretending sending water to 
Ethiopia one time makes you a superhero in reality. You'd be there like, 
24/7 doing charity work.

Now, I'm aware that, realistically you're not obligated to do this. And 
honestly neither is Batman in his own universe.

But meeting obligations doesn't make you Batman. Going above and beyond 
them doesn't make you Batman. Being Batman in our reality requires an 
almost complete sacrifice of yourself to the pursuit of justice. No family, 
no fame, no you but doing good deeds. That's what being Batman would be.

And probably none of us here, myself included are that.﻿

comments.text:
Seems to me that you're approaching the idea of Batman from a sociological 
and psychological point of view, maybe even a philosophical one . . . if 
you consider Batman's story to be a form of myth:

Sociological: Batman represents what is valued in our culture/society: 
strength, intelligence, wealth, and a little bit of vulnerability. After 
all, we cannot appreciate those who appear almighty, correct? Those with 
some trauma behind their stories, i.e. going through depression or poverty 
or abuse or all of the above, garner more sympathy from the public and 
become hailed as standards for high status. It's almost shallow; it's a lot 
like the simplification of human beings that John talks about so often. We 
prefer to see the pure greatness rather than the faults - and if we do see 
the faults, they are "in the stars".
Psychological: I don't know enough about the Batman story to know for sure, 
but it sounds like he may take on something similar to Joseph Campbell's 
Hero Myth. If you assume that his normal persona, Bruce Wayne, is the 
conscious while Batman is the unconscious . . . I mean, after all, he finds 
all of the bad guys in the night, when he is cloaked and masked. It is when 
he struggles against them that he struggles with his own faults (or so I 
can only assume - again, I don't know much about Batman, and this is mostly 
speculation.)
Philosophical: again, certain values and ideals. He may also represent the 
values we want in ourselves, i.e. strength to prevail and the knowledge to 
know that what we do is GOOD. It's not easy to know.
...the only other thing I could add to this would be wish fulfillment . . . 
wanting to be heroes and therefore writing out the heroes ourselves. You 
mentioned something very similar to that, Hank, with the strong white male 
issue. Actually, you pretty much hit it on the head.

. . . thoughts? Again, from a mythical standpoint, there's a lot of value 
to the Batman story, whether you hate him or love him.﻿

comments.author: Tiana Buchanan

comments.text:
Miles Morales is one of the best characters to point to when talking about 
representation. He is a great character and I love that little guy.

In the long run, I do not think handing mantles over to minority characters 
is a problem (even if people throw fits). It is the logical and best way to 
diversify your line up of heroes without having to go through the trials 
and tribulations of generating new heroic identities (which is almost 
always a big miss (but when it hits, it is practically a home run)).

What I think many people scoff at and take real offense to is the idea of 
taking an established character, like Wally West, and making him black 
(even though the character has been white for decades). There is nothing 
fundamentally "white" about Wally West but it irks people that the official 
representation of the character is now altered (perhaps irrevocably). I 
think this differs from issues like making Sherlock Holmes Asian because, 
outside of the old novels, there is nothing "official" about Sherlock. That 
"official-ness" is really just code for "only". So the only interpretation 
of a character you will get is this new version (where as, since Sherlock 
is free to the world, any one can make a Sherlock story).

This is why I really like what Marvel did with Fury. In an alternate 
universe, he was black. The movies made the black version really popular. 
In the main version of the Marvel Universe, Fury had a son who eventually 
rose up to become a prominent member of SHIELD, while at the same time the 
old (white) Fury is kept on the periphery and not given as central a role 
as his son. People who come into comics from the movies will see a black 
Nick Fury. People who have followed comics for decades will see both Fury 
Jr. and Fury Sr. It is an excellent compromise that satisfies almost 
everyone.

Having written that out, I now realize how much that resembles a passing of 
a mantle. Interesting.

comments.text:
Diversity for its own sake ends up only creating token characters that end 
up themselves personifying what we see later in the future as nothing more 
than offensive stereotypes. Also, I will point out that Falcon, Lucius Fox, 
Nick Fury, and a whole mess of other important characters, including a mass 
of characters in the Agents of SHIELD show? All not white. A lot of other 
characters as well, including one that is basically intrinsic to Captain 
America's character in the movies(And is getting her own series)? Are 
female. You say the movies underrepresent, but they really don't, and 
saying they Do only serves to marginalize the parts that the non-white 
non-male people play in these films, including Agent May, one of the most 
badass non-white female characters in the Marvel universe, or Sif, a 
character that may very well be getting a much bigger part coming soon, or 
Romanoff, a character that herself has a RIDICULOUS amount of backstory 
that is being courted for her own film, etc. Also, it's really hard to say 
that certain characters represent the default white man when they turn out 
to be not men at all, but aliens from another planet, and in many cases, 
not white or black or whatever, but commonly Green or Blue, oddly enough. 
To boil race down to skin color alone is a little bit racist, in a way, so 
careful there. When we say White Male, we have to consider what that 
actually means. Do we mean White Males from the UK and the commonwealth? Or 
white males from America? Or White Males from Scandinavia? Poland? Russia? 
Germany? Italy? Because all of these countries have very, VERY different 
cultures, and to conflate them all as just "White Males" is itself a little 
bit problematic. ﻿

comments.author: Daravenc

comments.text:
The amount of people trying to justifying their racism in the comments is 
unreal.

Look my friends, you can't deny that having an extreme saturation of the 
same kind of person, who is also the same kind of person that our society 
glorifies, glorified in every corner of our media, has a harmful effect. On 
pretty much anyone who doesn't fit that stereotype. And even on those who 
do, as they pretty much have a constant image of who they should be. Media 
has a trickle down effect and a feedback loop relationship with our society 
which you cannot deny.

Also, don't you find all these perfect white rich dudes to be a bit boring? 
Seeing the same person with pretty much the same experiences over and over 
again doesn't make for good media, irrelevant of the wider social 
consequences.

That doesn't mean to say you can't love and enjoy these characters. Like, I 
agree with both John and Hank to a certain extent. But at the same time, I 
love Batman regardless. He's a great character in that he actually has some 
flaws, he has cool gear and an awesome dramatic back story. And he goes 
against some great villains! But whilst I can enjoy Batman, I also can 
recognise how shitty (and sometimes how great) the character is, especially 
in the context of our society and it's problems. Batman doesn't tackle 
injustice, he tackles fictional injustice, glorified justice of beating up 
bank robbers who steal our hard earned money, and huge terrifying 
fairy-tale super villains who are fascinating in their own right. The 
injustices of our time are not fought by Batman, the injustices of poverty, 
of institutional racism, of governmental discrimination, of corruption, of 
human rights abuse. And maybe that's because one person (even a 
billionaire) can't tackle those things, however much he might try. Or maybe 
it's because batman is the same type of person as those behind the 
perpetuation of those injustices. Batman is great character, and one of the 
reasons why is because we can have these discussions and debates over him. 
But remember! Critical doesn't always mean negative.﻿

+Sexy scientist
There are many superheroes who are not white males, and hopefully 
children's parents can direct them to those comics. However, there are 
currently no superhero TV shows or movies with minority main characters. 
There are some with black people in teams or as sidekick characters. They 
don't exist, so parents can't direct their kids to watch them.

You say that it's possible that some kids feel this way (wonder why the 
heroes don't look like them). It's not just possible, it's prevalent. 
Source: actually listening to POC and other minorities when they talk about 
this and not assuming, as a white person, that I know how they feel.

A good place to see this is http://weneeddiversebooks.tumblr.com/. 
Sometimes they share interviews or essays written by diverse authors. When 
they talk about their childhoods, pretty much all of them discuss feeling 
like the heroes of stories were only white boys and only white men could be 
successful writers, but then they read a book with a protagonist like them 
or saw an author speak who was like them. They talk about how profoundly 
these experiences changed their lives. They say it's important. We need to 
listen to them.

comments.text:
+Sexy scientist That's because they are kids who are focussing on whatever 
their minds wander to first. If they have this particular perception, then 
it's no use telling them that they didn't "get it". The damage is done, so 
to speak. More importantly, however, I actually think you are right to say 
that kids who like a show will get the main message, e.g. "be honest, brave 
and do good things". However, talking about complexity, I think it is 
possible for a kid to like and embrace these messages and STILL be affected 
by the idea that the hero is not "like you". In other words, a black kid 
might love Superman and his values, but still be bothered by the fact that 
no hero (at least in the past) was black. It can be demotivating. "I want 
to be brave and all, but I see nobody that shows these values and also 
looks like me...Does that mean that people who look like me cannot be like 
that?!" Kids sometimes think that way.

comments.text:
The problem with one person being the source of change is multifaceted. 
 For one thing, for that person to be making those changes on their own 
means that they must be invested with lots of personal power.  People who 
gain that power are unlikely to relinquish it.  These leads to stagnation, 
where the leader who had so many good ideas to begin with fails to keep up 
the pace, and so ends up maintaining a new status quo (Look at Cuba.  many 
of the reforms of the communist government went a long way towards 
developing the nation as a modern, industrialized center, but after a few 
decades, the nation remains only revolutionary in 1960 terms).  It also 
means that the leader's efforts will be more and more invested in retaining 
that power rather than reforming (Lenin's early organization of the Soviets 
was seen by many socialists as a great step forward, but when the worker's 
councils started making decisions contrary to his own wishes, he used the 
party to wrest all meaningful control from the soviets).  If a leader does 
leave power on their own, once they're gone, what's to keep their reforms 
going?  (Lazaro Cardenas, president of Mexico, made many reforms empowering 
labor unions and organizing peasant self representation and land reform. 
 However, he stepped down after his term was up, and the his successors 
used his union reforms to control the unions so they represented the state, 
not the workers, and undid many of the agrarian reforms).  If power rests 
in one person, that person may not feel the effects of their own decisions, 
and so be unresponsive when policies don't work (Hugo Chavez and his 
successor, Nicolas Maduro, doubtless had good intentions with their 
currency and price controls.  However they've proven disastrous 
economically, but to change them would have clashed with their ideology, 
and so they remain).  

Power should remain in the hands of the people, and they should put their 
faith in ideas, not individuals.  Because individuals will always change, 
and eventually, will always fail.

comments.text:
I used to agree that Superman was such a simple, morally perfect character 
that he was not relatable.  However, I've recently had a change of heart 
regarding the character, so much so that I actually prefer him to Batman. 
 Superman's origin is simple, in All Star Superman it is summarized in five 
lines, "Doomed Planet. Desperate Scientists. Last Hope. Kindly Couple. 
Superman."  However, its the simplicity of the story that makes his 
character interesting. There is no event, no trauma, that led Superman to 
become who he is--Superman is simply an idealist. The complexity of 
Superman's character come from the friction created from rubbing Superman's 
idealism against say, Lex Luthor's extreme moral relativism. That struggle 
to truly lift up mankind, to do the right thing in a society that isn't 
comfortable tackling difficult problems or looking out for the vulnerable 
is an inherently human struggle.﻿

comments.author: mayanpaw

comments.text:
You can't win until you do it enough times that it becomes normal, as a 
creator, the first time I included a homosexual couple in my stories... the 
reaction wasn't nice, some were homophobic, some said I was just including 
them as token characters, some said I was misrepresenting LGBT people, some 
others said I made them too prevalent while others claimed I was somehow 
"downplaying their presence".

Then I introduced a second couple, then third, and the reaction became less 
violent, people simply started to accept their presence as a normal part of 
the world that didn't really merit any special attention (also the 
homophobes likely went away, win-win). Nowadays people sometimes say that 
they enjoy my portrayal of them, with   a vocal minority still bashing me. 
I'm sure that if enough creators do the same eventually both of these 
people will fade away, that is, no longer will my work be praised or 
criticized for it, it will just be a normal part of everyday life and 
culture, but until that happens we are stuck in the situation I described 
in the first paragraph.

+PowerMindAlchemist "All generalizations [are] false," which itself is a

Inherent contradictions aside, "the truth resists simplicity," is a

Sometimes the truth is simple, sometimes it's complicated in the sense that 
it's difficult to unravel.

comments.text:
I am so into this discussion because superheroes are MY JAM.  Certainly I 
agree with you Hank that comics SHOULD be where risks get taken, and 
sometimes they are; Gail Simone's run on Batgirl gave us one of the few 
trans women in the DCU, Batwoman herself is one of the relatively few 
lesbian superheroes, not to mention all the good things Marvel has been 
doing over the years.  I would like to see them take MORE risks, but one 
step at a time.  
I did disagree with the claim that Superman is unrelatable, because I think 
the problem is we live in a very Batman society- not just the character, 
but a cultural focus on cynicism and darkness- that we dismiss Superman 
based on how we imagine him.  I have actually heard that Superman is more 
popular than Batman in poorer areas, and I think that shows that our 
reality defines our choice of escapism: When all you want is to be cool and 
do cool stuff you want to be Batman, but when you feel that the weight of 
the world is crushing you then you want to be Superman.﻿

wrong with having predominantly white people. I would have a problem if it

not mind them being represented as such. However, a complete exclusion or

demographics of the average comic book reader of the 1940s through the

comments.text:
The idea that individuals have the power to make society better is not a 
new one - I think Plato coined the term benevolent dictator - and it is 
seemingly eternally attractive and powerful. It would be easy to talk about 
countries like Russia where the man at the top seems to have so much power 
and is seen by many as a potential or actual force for good but much more 
interesting is a conversation about countries like America or Britain. In 
the US, for example, the president is seen as and talked about as having 
wide-ranging powers even though in reality his (or, hopefully, one day, 
her) power is both formally and informally very limited. However, 'we' like 
the idea of a powerful individual calling the shots and it is also a useful 
propaganda tool. But then, that's because we are yet to move on from seeing 
human agency as something performed by individuals and starting to 
understand it as a result of group action.

And no wonder, seeing as understanding group agency is so much more 
complicated.﻿

comments.text:
Great episode Hank. I think that between this and John's previous video you 
pointed out a serious heroism in just everyday not sucking. 

However, I take a bit a of point with your complaint that every person is 
hot and male and white in movies. Its absolutely true though. However it's 
not really the media's duty to rebuke those stereotypes.

The media, or rather, the individual players that make up the broader role 
of mass publication, is in business to make money, not to make people feel 
accepted. And sure they might be able, through a concerted effort, break 
down the stereotypes and consciously cast and write more female or more 
racial actors and characters. But why would they? They stand nothing to 
gain from it, and a considerable amount to lose by alienating their core 
demographics. Sure they might, in theory, be opening up more demographics, 
but in all it would probably be a wash at best. As a business, what 
monetary sense does it make to change what already works?﻿

sense, but once again, that isn't reality. What I'm saying isn't an 
assumption, it is reality, I'm not saying what is wrong or right, I'm just

villain might work in your case because nobody is trying to relate to the 
villain, they want to relate to the hero. You can say what you want but you

that is most like them, the majority of consumers are white males, end of 
story. Don't believe it? Then just look at history, there are a diverse 
range of heros, yet it's always the ones where the hero is white that sell 
the most. Sorry if you don't like it, but I'm not going to lie to you 
because you don't want your feelings hurt. It's not racism that a person 
wants to cheer for somebody that is relatable to them, that's just how 
human psychology works. 

" "Well if 51% of moviegoers are white men then 100% of heroes have to be 
white men". Like as if every white viewer is from the KKK or some shit."

Except nobody is saying that? There is a thing called markets, lets say the 
percentage is 51%, that is still the majority. That is a market that fits a 
lot more material before it is exhausted. Say the black, Asian, women,  and 
Mexican markets consist of 10% each, well it is much faster to exhaust 
those markets, so you see less media marketed toward them. Of course there 
are people who will take those markets, but there isn't room enough for 
those markets as there is for the white market. That is why you see less 
material marketed toward minorities. And again, the fact that you don't 
like it doesn't change a god damn thing. Cry all you want, this is how it 
works and it's not going to change because you don't like it. The media is 
going to do what makes them the most money, they have no responsibility to 
do shit but that.
comments.author: Young Turk

comments.text:
+Damien Granz I don't even know where to start.  Are you saying that every 
villain in cinema is of some vilified "other" class?  Because that is 
patently untrue.  One could go down the list but I don't think it's 
necessary, just consult your memory.  It's also false that every hero is a 
heterosexual white male.  Last and most importantly, it isn't true that if 
a media production doesn't prominently feature people of color in their 
cast, or the struggle against sexism or heteronormativity in its narrative, 
than this is a reflection of laziness on the part of the storyteller, or an 
abdication of social responsibility.  It is neither.

It isn't even as though other points of view are not represented by 
Hollywood on either the big or small screen.  Some of the most popular 
films and TV shows showcase the alternative lifestyles and struggles of 
people who are different from the norm, from "Little People, Big World" to 
"Glee", "Gangland" to "Duck Dynasty".

Finally, if it is elites' responsibility to lead us rubes out of the 
darkness and into the light, I wonder who's banner of progress we ought to 
be marching under.  Differences in the nature and direction of social 
problems and progress abound, and I'm sure there's as wide a difference 
between Bill and Melinda Gates' conception of the good and Charles and 
David Koch.  Peter Thiel of Paypal fame and John Mackey of WholeFoods 
inevitably have very different visions of how to change the world for the 
better than George Soros or Warren Buffet.  Even places like Chik-fil-a and 
Hobby Lobby are behaving as moral actors and not just greedy capitalists, 
as evidenced by their taking unpopular positions based on principle over 
profit.  My question is... is this really what we want?  To be buying a 
little social justice with our Starbucks, or a little traditional values 
with our chicken sandwich?  Must everything that isn't obviously trying to 
advance some cause by necessity be an impediment to it?  And should we be 
turning social justice into a commodity to be bought as cheaply as a basket 
of locally grown, certified organic, farm fresh, cruelty-free consumer 
goods?

comments.text:
+MarlonOwnsYourCake I think you're mostly right and we're seeing that now 
infact.  Where the culture goes, so too go the entrepreneurs.  Rising 
demand for niche games featuring non-stereotypical characters, esoteric 
plotlines, and experimental game design?  Great!  Many an indie game 
developer is there to satisfy.  I just don't understand why people expect 
mainstream, big studio, big budget films to represent niche or minority 
viewpoints, when the whole reason they exist is to appeal to as wide an 
audience as possible (ie, the majority interest). 

In a way it's all very democratic... 50% + 1 prefer something one way, then 
that's what 100% get.  Thankfully we have smaller producers to satisfy 
minority tastes.  I recall about a decade ago being impressed at the speed 
with which whole wheat foods made their way onto crowded store shelves and 
restaurant menus, and now we have the gluten-free mania that affects an 
even smaller segment of the population and has been adopted even faster by 
the market.  I wonder just how long it would take to cater to these 
peculiar tastes and preferences if the food we all consumed was decided by 
majority opinion, or some other system that's supposed to proportionally 
represent the diversity of wants, needs and demands of 310 million people.
comments.author: xxcrysad3000xx

comments.text:
Actually, right now is the PERFECT time to make money off of the 
representation of minorities as there are a ton of civil rights issues and 
feminist issues happening in American culture right now and we have a black 
president and all that jazz. Like Dove is not doing their "real beauty" 
campaign because they care about how women see themselves...altough I'm 
sure some of the people involved do. It happened because it's marketable 
right now, just like in the 70s. That's point number one.
Point number two is that's the biggest problem with capitalism when applied 
to things outside the strict, cold, hard, impersonal exchange of goods and 
services. That it's a fantastic system for making money and for getting 
high quality products into the market in cases where quality is easily 
measurable. But in cases where either you can't really opt out of something 
(healthcare/schools) or where quality is subjective (art/media) it becomes 
problematic and limiting. It forces people to think like corporations and 
only getting money when it's not as advantageous.
Point umber three is it is a storyteller's responsibility to think about 
how people see the world and ways to represent the average person. For 
instance Spiderman is a hero all about people who are ignored and outcast 
or discriminated against so it would make sense to have something like a 
black Peter Parker. You should be able to have a hero who's female in a 
story and not have it be about her being female but about her being a 
person. Every storyteller has the responsibility to say something that 
hasn't been said, to say something true, and to shape how people see 
things. And for the most part movies have been using the same stuff over 
and over.

But that's mostly just my opinion.

comments.author: Joseph Beck

comments.text:
+Young Turk  I love that you feel that businesses can take land they have 
no more right to than anybody else, and resources that they don't have more 
right to than anybody else, and make money off of it, and that they don't 
have to owe anybody anything, as if how capital is built is just by John 
Galt flexing hard until a hammer and some iron appears in his hands from 
the ether and only he's wise and powerful enough to shape it.

Businesses owe their workers and customers and society pretty much 
everything they have. They owe society for allowing them access to the 
nation's land and resources. They owe their workers for shaping those 
resources into useful things. They owe their customers for paying for those 
resources. Even the basic idea that somebody has 'rights' or 'right to 
property' is something they owe society, because if society decided they 
didn't have a right that property it'd be gone in an instant, and that's 
pretty much precisely what happens when the state sues you or society 
allows a member to sue you.

Yes, if you direct or shape land and resource in a way that makes it worth 
more, you should take a helping of that extra fat. But the idea that you 
pounding the last nail into a project that is made of a million nails makes 
that entire project yours and anybody that says otherwise can fuck off is, 
at best stupid and at worst dangerous for anybody but the guy that pounded 
the last nail.

Businesses have a responsibility to society by both implicit legal 
agreements and subjective social contract agreements, and when it GROSSLY 
fails to live up to that agreement, you bet your ass that shit should be 
snatched back up.

Business didn't build the whole of reality and Earth to charge rent out of 
it. That the free market is given reigns by a lawfully appointed and 
democratically controlled state at all over the public good is subjective 
on the idea that the free market can direct these goods in a profitable and 
meaningful way for the betterment of the society (and its customers) as a 
whole.

And the day they forget it, as you seem to, and believe that they are 
beholden to nothing more than their own feudal avarice as if God himself 
directly gave the world to them is exactly the day they should be *at best* 
politely thrown out on their ass, and depending on the severity of their 
inability to with hold their end of the social contract (the one enforced 
by reality that basically states "We won't kill you and suck the marrow 
from your bones for no other reason than the joy it brings my heart to do 
so, if you agree to similarly place nice with us in like turn") probably 
punished or rehabilitated more forcefully.

As a member of almost every western nation, you, and every single other 
citizen are legal owners of that nation. That's part of the "government by 
the people, for the people" thing. You have a voice in its governance, and 
that governance includes allocation of its resource. Yes, you don't have 
the sole voice; you share it with every other citizen, not much differently 
than any other organization or corporation.

So tell me, as a member of the effective corporation known as 'we the 
people', if the only thing I'm beholden to is my own personal desires, why 
I should put up with businesses that feel like I'm their cattle? Because 
the only reason you should is if you are.

Because they aren't magically any more entitled to shit than you are.

Really this stupid ass rationalization is the core of why people continue 
to allow corporations and authoritative governments fuck them, because they 
feel that the latter are entitled to the entire universe and they aren't. 
Best case scenario is you're fucking yourself.

Honestly your own ideals don't even hold remote water legally anyways. You 
claim back and forth that anybody with economic education would agree with 
you while simultaneously showing you have or severely failed to comprehend 
any in both legal precedence or economic law.

Consider the moment you open up a business to the public, you have to 
follow laws like anti-discrimination law and the like specifically because 
business operates at the pleasure of society and the customer, and not the 
other way around.

And again, the moment you think otherwise is the moment you give up your 
own rights.

And you might be in a hurry to surrender your and our rights together as 
fast as possible, but I sure as hell am not in a hurry to join you and I 
suggest anybody with sense not follow you.

Yes the villains all in come in a variety, but the good guys, and 
especially the protagonists, are proportionally mostly white males. When it 
comes to depicting queer people, you'll be hard pressed to find any who 
aren't portrayed as villains or mentally stable. (the game theorists 
youtube channel has a video on this). And you can't look at modern warfare 
games without realizing a lot of the villains in the game are 'Terrorists' 
or Communist Russians and other such non-white american dudes. I know this 
isn't a conspiracy, I don't believe in that idiotic stuff, but there is a 
one sided representation in media, and that's because it's the status quo. 
Proper representation is important and powerful, and right now there are a 
lot of people not being represented in a lot of media.

My last paragraph is referring to the chunky pasta sauce experiment. 
Jimquisition has a video about it on the Escapist channel. But to summarize 
here: pasta sauce used to only sell a single type - 'smooth'. Company A 
wants to beat company B so they ask a dude to make the perfect pasta sauce, 
Dude realised that people are more or less split between chunky, smooth and 
spicy and tells the company to start making a variety of sauce, despite the 
fact that no customer ever said they even wanted chunky pasta sauce cause 
it *never existed* in the market before. Company makes lots of money. 
Huzzah! Business via diversifying products.

If you can't see how women are objectified in media and shamed when they 
try to point it out (eg. the current flack a lot of women in the game and 
comic industry are getting right now, just look up GamerGate) then I say 
you're ignoring how the world works right now.

Francisco was founded in 1848.The Harlem Renaissance began in 1918. Woman's 
Suffrage 1850's. These groups fought in (in the case of woman - supported) 
every US war, invented, became politicians, doctors, lawyers, etc. before 
ANY of these comics were created. But because of the OVERALL racial tension 
and White Male majority oppression that existed and exists in the US, they 
were left out of the "HERO" archetype when the comics were first written. 
And when we celebrate these same "hero's" today w/o acknowledging the fault 
in their skewed definition of American "hero" STILL existing, it is the 
same as STILL supporting the wrongs they did when creating the characters 
in the first place.

That is why the idea's like allowing the new Captain America to be Black is 
happening. They are not rewriting history by making him Black. They are 
REMOVING omissions from our nations race bias history in defining its 
HERO's. If you flew a B52 Bomber over Europe in WW2 you knew that most 
pilots did not return safely until the Tuskegee Airmen escorted. Survival 
percentage jumped from high 30's to around 96%. Those Black men were WW2 
hero's and don't deserve to be only celebrated by on small minority. They 
deserve to be celebrated by every US citizen. The WIndtalkers, The 54th 
Massachusetts Volunteer Infantry, The 999th Field Artillery, African 
American battalions in Patton’s Third Army, Etc, etc.

It was WRONG (all be it profitable and non-controversial) to make all the 
original "hero's" White males and it's wrong to continue celebrating that 
ideal today.

comments.text:
I'm sick and tired of hearing that being a white male is a bad thing. 
Honestly, as a WHITE MALE in NYC I grew up with criticism galore. My 
education throughout the past 15 years has reinforced the idea that white 
men have been the cruelest, most inhumane, inconsiderate people for 
essentially all history. I was the MINORITY in ALL of my schools, and had 
few role models to look up to. Other students would say, "Oh you can't 
dance, you're too WHITE!" or "You won't be as good at sports, you're too 
white." Yeah I get it. I'm white. White people did some sucky things in the 
past. Don't group me together with those people. But why do we have to look 
at FICTIONAL HEROES and say, "Oh, we must make these people as relative as 
possible and not to set moral and virtuous standards, but instead CHANGE 
THE AMOUNT OF MELATONIN." OH MY GOSH. Everyone is different, and we ought 
to celebrate that. But appealing to each and every type of person by 
rewriting famous characters is a shame. When I look at people, I don't see 
there appearance. White, Black, Asian, Middle Eastern, etc. I look at their 
hearts. I look at their values. What they love. What they think about most. 
And I say to myself, that person can do so much, or how can I encourage 
that person to keep being awesome? These are the things we should think 
about. Hank, I loved that you took the approach to Batman to show that he 
is the only person unaffected by corruption. For that you are right. It is 
Batman's DILIGENCE that makes him a hero. But please, show the world that 
we truly have moved on from the staples of outward appearance.
My apologies for this rant.
DFTBA﻿

comments.text:
I'm concerned that you're being inconsistent in how you use the word 
"representation".  You seem to be using it to refer to two similar but 
distinct ideas.  You first say that Batman represents the anger and 
frustration of all of us, in the sense that he serves as a personification 
of it.  That, I agree with.

The problem arises when you then use "representation" to mean "how 
frequently members of certain racial, ethnic, or gender groups are shown in 
media", and don't clarify that you're using it to mean something different 
than you did originally.  Because then you imply that (for example) it's 
impossible or inappropriate for women or black people to identify with the 
frustration or anger of Batman.  That's a bad idea, because a) it's false, 
b) it's widely-accepted (particularly in social justice circles), and c) it 
promotes exclusion and self-segregation.

Now, to clarify; I definitely agree that we should be doing a better job of 
showing ethnic and gender diversity in our media.  I just think if our 
reason for it is "because people can't/won't/shouldn't relate to people of 
a different gender/ethnicity", we are promoting some *very* stupid ideas.﻿

comments.text:
I've never found that in comics, or in the movies they are turned into, 
that its about representing a certain group.  I feel that both different 
ethnicity and socio-economic levels are represented evenly.  The only main 
line of thinking I see is that absolute power corrupts.  This is why large 
government, military groups, and crime syndicates are always the ones whom 
they are fighting against.  The biggest difference I'm seeing is in main 
character personalities.  In the comics they may be been, like batman, 
depressed and angry, but they led them to learn a higher sense of justice.  
With that they would defy all odds and risk all to do the right thing, 
simply because it was right.  We see personal vendettas get in the way far 
too often in the movies in an attempt to humanize characters and make them 
more relatable.  In my opinion, this kinda takes the super out of the 
hero.  This aspect is also what allowed normal citizens become, at least 
for a moment, a hero.  It wasn't about the powers, it was about making the 
choice and doing what is right.

A side note:  A large problem with the movies now of days is that they are 
afraid to have evil people.  People who are just bad because they are bad.  
Hydra is trying to save the world.  Bane is equalizing justice and removing 
inequality even if he must constantly experience pain to do it or suffer to 
save a child.  Loki is evil only because of bad choices and secrets made by 
his father; the revelation of which broke his heart in addition to the pain 
he felt of never being able to be king despite being a better candidate 
then his pompous and immature brother.  In this sense, it's everyone's 
fault but his.  This concept separates common people from being better as 
we've formed a line.  You can't have a large or powerful organization doing 
good as it can become corrupt.  You can't step up as a senator or mayor 
because you become corrupt.  You can't fight evil because they have free 
will and you stopping them or hurting them is evil.  You can't even always 
help out the hero because they break the law as vigilantes so they are bad 
too.  In the movies we create a subjective sense of what is right and 
wrong.  True, this exists in the real world, but why can we no longer 
simply have an evil villain who is simply evil and the hero fighting 
against him simply because it's right?

The comics were never about representing a certain group of people or 
demonizing others.  Comics were simple.  Good and evil.  Most super hero's 
can't change the world.  Even if they could, they wouldn't.  (look up 
Justice Lords)  Evil was placed before them and did what they could to stop 
it.﻿

comments.text:
Superman is neither simple nor unrelatable. He has few flaws, but flaws are 
not the only condition for complexity, nor is it impossible to relate to 
someone with fewer flaws than you.  Superman, when written well, can be 
tremendously compelling and profoundly human.  In both subtle and unsubtle 
ways, he can mirror the best parts of ourselves and when we recognize 
those, we can simultaneously become endeared to the strength of our own 
potential for goodness and ashamed at how far we individually fall from it. 
  It's perhaps harder to write a character well when you don't have a bunch 
of flaws to mine for easy conflict, but it's far from impossible.

Good is just as relateable as evil.  Though it's easier sometimes to make 
the latter feel like home, in truth we are citizens of both nations 
constantly getting our passports stamped at the border.﻿

comments.text:
"In the end, I saw Superman not as a superhero or even a science fiction 
character, but as a story of Everyman. We’re all Superman in our own 
adventures. We have our own Fortresses of Solitude we retreat to, with our 
own special collections of valued stuff, our own super–pets, our own 
“Bottle Cities” that we feel guilty for neglecting. We have our own peers 
and rivals and bizarre emotional or moral tangles to deal with. 
I felt I’d really grasped the concept when I saw him as Everyman, or rather 
as the dreamself of Everyman. That “S” is the radiant emblem of divinity we 
reveal when we rip off our stuffy shirts, our social masks, our neuroses, 
our constructed selves, and become who we truly are. 
Batman is obviously much cooler, but that’s because he’s a very energetic 
and adolescent fantasy character: a handsome billionaire playboy in black 
leather with a butler at this beck and call, better cars and gadgetry than 
James Bond, a horde of fetish femme fatales baying around his heels and no 
boss. That guy’s Superman day and night. 
Superman grew up baling hay on a farm. He goes to work, for a boss, in an 
office. He pines after a hard–working gal. Only when he tears off his shirt 
does that heroic, ideal inner self come to life. That’s actually a much 
more adult fantasy than the one Batman’s peddling but it also makes 
Superman a little harder to sell. He’s much more of a working class 
superhero, which is why we ended the whole book with the image of a 
laboring Superman. 
He’s Everyman operating on a sci–fi Paul Bunyan scale. His worries and 
emotional problems are the same as ours"
 -Grant Morrison, author of All-Star Superman﻿

comments.text:
+N3rdSci3nc3 I have a few points with your counter argument.

First, evidence gathered through research studies is not discarded when it 
ceases to match reality. It would be foolish to deny the kind of 
longitudinal insight into phenomena that could be derived from that 
information. What I am saying is that people and society change over time. 
Just because things don't match now, it doesn't mean it didn't mean 
something at the time (assuming that the research process itself was 
sound). So, discarding evidence because thats not how things are now isn't 
a thing.  

Second, the conclusion is not final. It is still a hot topic in my field 
(criminology). I agree, and want to believe myself, that video games do not 
have a negative effect. Research does tend to support that violent media 
and real world violence are not connected. We will see. It is difficult to 
capture these concepts in a meaningful way through research, which is why 
so many similar studies need to be conducted for any given phenomena. 

Third, you have not taken the argument to its logical extreme. You have 
taken it to be a statement about causality, which you then knock down in 
strawman fashion. Their argument was a statement about correlation, not 
causality.

comments.author: N3rdSci3nc3

comments.text:
+N3rdSci3nc3 I am afraid that you are wrong. It has NOT been proven because 
proof does not exist in the social sciences. Scientific research into 
social issues revolves around the accumulation of evidence that suggests 
that something is more likely to be true. Proof, however much it is spoken 
of in common language, only exists in math. 

I understand what you are saying about the media, but it is not the case 
that the media has been discounted as an influence on individuals. On the 
contrary, the notion that the media influences individual decision-making 
is widely accepted by social scientists. The degree of influence, however, 
is contested because there are so many influences converging on individuals 
at any given point in space and time.

To build on your example, if you take what I said above into consideration, 
then it is hardly surprising that a causal link has not been found between 
violent video game use and violent criminal acts. First, research into 
social issues focuses on the identification of correlations between 
phenomena. Second, only evidence, rather than proof, is accumulated. This 
means that no final conclusions can be made that would fully resolve a 
given issue. Third, all evidence is interpreted by the researcher, who has 
their own biases, which opens the possibility for mistaking it as 
supporting something that it does not. So, violent media forms may or may 
not still influence one or more factors that contribute to 
violence. Complicated, right? 

That's why we're here watching +vlogbrothers! Open your mind to the 
possibility of other options and think critically my friend. You are right 
to challenge, but wrong to assume that you know truth when speaking about 
something that is fundamentally social.
comments.author: Phillippe Bourbeau

comments.text:
It is not just that all simplifications are lies. All models of the 
universe or its parts are inexact and incomplete. Therefore, despite their 
usefulness and approximate applicability, they are necessarily wrong.

Some are easier to understand than others. Some are better at explaining 
than others. Some are better at predicting than others. Some are more moral 
than others. Some of them are more wrong than others. Some are by all 
counts *just plain better than others*. But all of them are necessarily 
wrong.

This wrongness is what I think that Hank is pointing out as a *kind* of 
lie. And this kind of lie is an unavoidable part of everything that we 
think and do. I think that this is hard to accept, but it is also an 
important thing to accept. So much evil has been performed because of 
certainty.﻿
comments.author: David Johnston

Well, then we can put the cap on this right now. Demographically percentage

And, for the record, while 31%-36% is a minority, no other political group

comments.author: houdini2233

comments.text:
+houdini2233 "That still doesnt make white males the minority compared to 
every other male/female ethnicity demographic"

Well, are we talking about actual definition or common usage?

By definition, anything over 50% is a majority and anything under is a 
minority. If, however, a group is a higher percentage than all other 
separate groups, you have a plurality.

So, yes, because 33% is less than 50%, it is a minority and all the others 
against is the majority. But if 33% is the highest percent of any of the 
groups, then white men make up the plurality.

Now, in the common usage, the group that has the highest visibility and 
vocality, usually the one with the power, is thought to be the majority.

And it is very debatable about who is the majority in the USA right now. A 
small 10% can be the one with the most power depending on the issue. And a 
single person could be the majority when we speak of the attention directed 
to say an outbreak of a disease.

Khan, has been so popular that her first comic has been reprinted five 
times, with an initial printing of 50,000 copies. Very few comics reach 
this milestone. Source: 
http://www.dailydot.com/geek/ms-marvel-kamala-khan-gets-sixth-printing/)  
Secondly, many comic book readers are not white or male. For instance, 
women make up 46.67% of the comic book audience. Source: 
http://comicsbeat.com/market-research-says-46-female-comic-fans/
Tangentially, Japan is much less racially diverse than the US, so saying 
American media doesn't need to have representation because Japanese media 
doesn't is disingenuous. Source: 
http://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/worldviews/wp/2013/05/16/a-revealing-map-of-the-worlds-most-and-least-ethnically-diverse-countries/ 
(I'm not saying Japanese media shouldn't have representation; all 
representation is good.)
I don't know much about Bollywood, but it appears that some people in the 
industry recognize the problem of lack of diversity and are taking some 
steps to rectify it. Source: 
http://epaper.timesofindia.com/Repository/ml.asp?Ref=VE9JS00vMjAxMS8wNy8xOCNBcjAxMTAx
comments.author: nadiact1000

comments.text:
I have to dissagree with you there hank. I think superman is a very complex 
character. If you take away his dead alien parents, his powers fueld by 
yellow sun radiation, and the nice costume, you get a story about an 
immigrant who pursues for the protection, and equality of the citizens of 
the city he lives in. BUT because he has these powers, he had to choose if 
he wanted to use them, and if it werent for his humbling upbringing by the 
kents, he could have been the most powerful villian that the DC universe 
would have to face. Even as a hero, he has to dial his powers down, so he 
doesnt intentionally kill a villain. 
I do think batman is a good character, but hes just a scared and angry 
child, with the money to fund his crime fighting. But i prefer it when hes 
fighting along side the bat family, because it just shows how a man dressed 
as a bat can influence others to make the world better. And then he has a 
surrogate family, and the writers dont have to fall back on the "im a 
loner" or the "i work alone" batman that i really really hate (im looking 
at you Frank Miller)﻿
comments.author: tardisblue1963
